title: 103_hr3967
content: The "Helium Act of 1994" is amended to grant authority to the Secretary in sections 3, 4, and 5. The Secretary has the authority to enter agreements with private parties for the recovery and disposal of helium on Federal lands. These agreements must be fair and reasonable, and the Secretary may grant leasehold rights for helium recovery. Helium sales can only be made to private parties with whom the Secretary has an agreement for recovery and disposal. Agreements are subject to rules and regulations set by the Secretary and must consider existing rights of Federal oil and gas lessees. The Secretary has the authority to store, transport, and sell helium in accordance with the Helium Act of 1994. They are also authorized to monitor helium production and reserves in the United States and prepare reports on helium quantities. The Secretary has the authority to store, transport, and sell helium in accordance with the Helium Act of 1994. They are also authorized to monitor helium production and reserves in the United States and prepare reports on helium quantities. SEC. 4. STORAGE AND TRANSPORTATION OF CRUDE HELIUM. The Secretary is authorized to store and transport crude helium, operate existing storage facilities, and dispose of related equipment and property within one year of the Helium Act of 1994 enactment. The United States is authorized to dispose of facilities, equipment, and property used for helium production in accordance with laws governing surplus properties. Proceeds from the sale will be treated as moneys received under the Helium Act, with costs covered by the helium production fund. This does not apply to essential facilities or equipment. The Helium Act of 1994 allows for the disposal of facilities and property necessary for helium storage and transportation. Existing contracts for the purchase of refined helium will remain in effect until the disposal of these facilities, with termination costs covered by the helium production fund. The Helium Act of 1994 authorizes the Secretary to impose fees on individuals for helium storage, transportation, and withdrawal services to cover the full costs. Fees collected will be considered moneys received under the Act. Section 6 of the Helium Act of 1994 is amended to require persons who have entered into contracts to purchase crude helium from the Secretary. Sales of crude helium will be determined by the Secretary in consultation with the helium industry to minimize market disruption. The Helium Act of 1994 is amended to require repayment of funds to the United States by October 1, 1993. The price of crude helium sold by the Secretary must not be less than a calculated amount based on outstanding repayable amounts and volume of helium owned by the US. Subsection (d) is also amended. The Helium Act of 1994 is amended to require repayment of funds to the United States by October 1, 1993. Subsection (d) is amended to specify that all moneys received from the sale of helium on Federal lands shall be paid to the Treasury. Subsection (e) is repealed, and subsection (f) is amended to require excess funds in a specific fund to be paid to the Treasury annually. Upon repayment of all amounts, the fund established under this section will be terminated, and all received moneys will be deposited in the Treasury as General Revenues. SEC. 5. ELIMINATION OF STOCKPILE. Section 8 is amended to read as follows: "SEC. 8. ELIMINATION OF STOCKPILE." The Secretary annually reviews US helium reserves to determine their expected life. Sales of excess helium reserves must start by January 1, 2004, to dispose of reserves over 600 million cubic feet by January 1, 2014, at prices ensuring repayment. The Secretary must ensure repayment of amounts to the Treasury under section 6(c) regardless of the discovery of additional helium reserves. Repeal of authority to borrow under sections 12 and 15.
